user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_unmount:
```c
int lfs_unmount(lfs_t *lfs) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_unmount(%p)", (void*)lfs);

    err = lfs_unmount_(lfs);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_unmount -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function lfs_unmount:
static int lfs_unmount_(lfs_t *lfs) {
    return lfs_deinit(lfs);
}
...
static int lfs_deinit(lfs_t *lfs) {
    // free allocated memory
    if (!lfs->cfg->read_buffer) {
        lfs_free(lfs->rcache.buffer);
    }

    if (!lfs->cfg->prog_buffer) {
        lfs_free(lfs->pcache.buffer);
    }

    if (!lfs->cfg->lookahead_buffer) {
        lfs_free(lfs->lookahead.buffer);
    }

    return 0;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
lfs_free(lfs->pcache.buffer);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No. The fragment calls lfs_free(lfs->pcache.buffer), which is a deallocation call and does not invoke any of the <string.h> functions named in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn). Therefore, based on the shown code there is no direct use of string.h functions and no violation of Rule 21.17. (If lfs_free’s implementation internally used a <string.h> routine incorrectly, that internal use would need separate review, but nothing in the provided fragment violates Rule 21.17.)
